Award.AwardTitle: Laser Spectroscopy of Ions and Clusters
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this award, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms (CSDM-A) Program of the Division of Chemistry, Professor Richard Saykally of the University of California - Berkeley and his graduate research students are investigating structure and dynamics of small clusters of water as well as water clusters containing other atmospherically-abundant molecules (nitrogen, oxygen, and small hydrocarbons). Specifically, Prof. Saykally and his group will probe water clusters produced in the laboratory with modern THz light sources.

The ultimate goal of the work by Professor Saykally and his group is to develop a better quantitative understanding of the complex interactions in water. Results of this work could have profound impacts in biology and environmental science. In addition, Prof. Saykally will help to train a new generation of scientists skilled in cutting-edge research. Prof. Saykally and his colleagues are also involved in scientific outreach, including the Math, Science and Engineering Resource Support (MASERS) program, which brings hands-on science activities and science professionals into middle schools in the San Francisco Bay area.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Water is the most fundamental substance on our planet, covering 2/3 of the planet’s surface and comprising the same fraction of the human body. Perhaps surprisingly, and despite centuries of study, we still lack the complete understanding of this remarkably complicated substance necessary for accurate and reliable prediction and modeling of its behavior in vitally important contexts, e.g. living cells. For example, we still do not even understand the details of how liquid water evaporates! Clearly, enhancing our understanding of water’s intrinsic nature will impact many areas of science and technology. A detailed characterization of the nature of water clusters and clusters of water with other fundamental molecules will facilitate their detection and modeling in applied contexts, e.g. chemistry and photophysics of the atmosphere, methane clathrates-the largest known reservoir of hydrocarbons on the planet. A total of 13 papers were published by our group on various problems involving water and aqueous solutions. 

 This project has produced large amounts of new data that describe the intimate details of how water molecules interact with one another, through the spectroscopic and theoretical study of small water clusters. We have developed new techniques and instruments for measuring highly detailed spectra of water clusters, and have applied them for the investigation of clusters containing up to eight water molecules. We seek to understand every detail of how two, three, four, etc. molecules of water interact to yield the complex nature of the extended hydrogen bond network of the liquid and ice. For example, we have recently published a study of the water octamer, demonstrating the “ice cube” structure and showing how the network of hydrogen bonds rearranges- even at the zero of temperature- by quantum mechanical tunneling.   

We have investigated the mechanism of water evaporation by a novel method, employing beams of micron-sized water droplets evaporating in a vacuum, and measuring the temperature of the evaporatively-cooled droplets with Raman laser spectroscopy. We have published a paper comparing the evaporation rates of pure water droplets and droplets of water containing acetic acid- a naturally occurring chemical that strongly adsorbs to the droplet surface, finding no significant difference in these rates. So far, it appears that water droplets, such as those comprising atmospheric clouds, evaporate at very nearly the maximum possible value, even when the droplets are contaminated with various atmospheric molecules.  This is important, because knowledge of the evaporation dynamics is currently one of the largest uncertainties in modeling terrestrial climate.

This research program has trained significant numbers of postdoctorals, Ph.D.s, and undergraduates in state-of-the-art research, including a significant number of women (21 women have received Ph.D.s under the PI, out of a total of 71 PhDs). The PI has strived to interface with the public through public lectures, the popular press, and other media (see website http://www.cchem.berkeley.edu/~rjsgrp/), as opportunities arise (e.g, the recent on-line interview and popular article, "Five Things We Still Don’t Know About Water" in Nautilis; the PBS film/book/website series Sacred Balance, which includes a section featuring the PI on the nature of water. The Saykally group has interfaced with faculty from minority-dominated institutions. As described above, Professor Wei Lin, from the University of Texas-Brownsville spent two summers at Berkeley, working with my group. Several joint papers on hydrocarbon clathrate systems will be published on this work. Two NSF-supported students graduated with Masters Degrees (Kaitlin Duffey and Nik Hlavacek) and have taken jobs in a teaching university and the water processing industry, respectively. A new first-year grad student (Will Cole) has joined my group to work on the quantum cascade laser effort. One undergraduate (Xiaotian Ma) began his graduate work in the Physics Department MIT this year, and another (Akbar Sheik) worked with Will Cole on the Terahertz laser experiment.

Our MASERS middle school science enhancement program has been temporarily discontinued at the Piedmont Middle School due to the necessity to focus on curriculum revisions mandated by the Common Core standards. The overall plan, pursued for a decade, has been for groups of graduate students from Berkeley, tutored by the Berkeley Community Resources for Science staff, to prefect their presentations at the Piedmont Middle School, and then take them to other middle schools in Alameda County. Recently, two Berkeley middle schools were included in the program, and extension to the third Berkeley school is in progress. Since its inception, partial funding for the MASERS program was available from residual funds from our older teacher enhancement program, Science for Science Teachers (S4ST), but these have now been expended. The goal is for the programs to become self-sustaining in the respective schools, which has largely been achieved, but some funding will be needed to develop new presentations. I am currently seeking funding sources for this purpose.
